CatDescriptText: George Gedman, conductor, 16th ward and William Fudge Jr., unemployed steel worker, Donora, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, February 4, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think the names of juveniles who commit felonies, as distinguished from misdemeanors, should be published in the newspapers?"  George Gedman's answer reads: "if the crime's real serious, I think the name should be published, but if it's a minor offense, the name should be withheld."  William Fudge Jr.'s answer reads: "I think that since they are youngsters, the names should be kept out... It doesn't help things at all to publish the names and, matter of fact, it makes things worse."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of George Gedman wearing jacket with upturned collar standing on sidewalk in front of window; Portrait of William Fudge Jr. wearing fedora, moustache, and grid patterned coat with upturned collar, holding light colored object in left arm, standing in front of Drake-Kapphan Pianos, Smithfield Street, Downtown
